            "abstract": "What is the reason we train our model? the most relevant features are used to train our model",
            "confidence": 0.47172868251800537,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.47172868251800537,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "confidence": 0.37827855348587036,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.37827855348587036,
            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

        {
            "abstract": "What is an example of steps below? 1.",
            "confidence": 0.4609068036079407,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.4609068036079407,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",
            "triple": [
                "my:example",
                "my:{subj}_of_{obj}",
                "my:step_below"

            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer.         {
            "abstract": "What kind of features are they? column generation",
            "confidence": 0.4387136399745941,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.4387136399745941,
            "sentence": "To ensure transparency and explainability in our credit approval decisions, we use three different explanatory models: BooleanRuleCG, LogisticRuleRegression, and Generalized Linear Rule Models (GLRM). These models help us understand the reasoning behind the decisions made by our XGBoost model. 1. **BooleanRuleCG (BRCG):** The BooleanRuleCG (BRCG) algorithm generates a set of simple boolean rules using a genetic algorithm. These rules can explain the decisions made by the predictive model, even for complex non-linear relationships. BRCG is designed to produce either a disjunctive normal form (DNF) or a conjunctive normal form (CNF) rule to predict whether an applicant will repay the loan on time. A DNF rule corresponds to an individual rule in the rule set, where the AND clauses in the DNF correspond to individual rules in the rule set. The algorithm uses column generation to search the space of possible clauses, which is exponential in size. The training accuracy of the BRCG model is 0.71, and the test accuracy is 0.69. 2. **LogisticRuleRegression (LRR):** The LogisticRuleRegression (LRR) algorithm fits a logistic regression model using rule-based features and is capable of generating interpretable rules that can explain the decision-making process. It uses column generation to generate promising candidates from the space of all possible rules, including unbinarized ordinal features in addition to rules. The complexity parameters lambda0 and lambda1 penalize the number of rules included in the model and the number of conditions in each rule. The training accuracy of the LRR model is 0.74, and the test accuracy is 0.72. 3. **Generalized Linear Rule Model (GLRM):** The Generalized Linear Rule Model (GLRM) algorithm extends the rule-based explanatory model by allowing for more general linear relationships. It produces models that are weighted combinations of rules, which give insight into loan repayment predictability. The algorithm also has the option of combining rules with linear terms. The model output predicts the probability of repaying on time (Y=1). The training accuracy of the CEMExplainer algorithm is 0.73, and the test accuracy is 0.72.",

        {
            "abstract": "What is an example of something Our system supports? XAI algorithms",
            "confidence": 0.3510650396347046,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3510650396347046,
            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

        {
            "abstract": "What is an example of something we use? the AI Fairness 360 toolkit",
            "confidence": 0.3679012656211853,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3679012656211853,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "confidence": 0.39481276273727417,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.39481276273727417,
            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

            "abstract": "What is an example of something we use to mitigate bias in the training dataset? the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package",
            "confidence": 0.3844747543334961,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3844747543334961,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed.             "confidence": 0.3458390235900879,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3458390235900879,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "abstract": "While what do we use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics? During the development of the machine learning model",
            "confidence": 0.4283352494239807,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.4283352494239807,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "sentence": "Meaning | Monotonicity Constraint (with respect to probability of bad = 1) --- | --Age | None Consolidated version of risk markers | Monotonically Decreasing Months Since Oldest Trade Open | Monotonically Decreasing Months Since Most Recent Trade Open | Monotonically Decreasing Average Months in File | Monotonically Decreasing Number Satisfactory Trades | Monotonically Decreasing Number Trades 60+ Ever | Monotonically Decreasing Number Trades 90+ Ever | Monotonically Decreasing Percent Trades Never Delinquent | Monotonically Decreasing Months Since Most Recent Delinquency | Monotonically Decreasing Max Delinquency/Public Records Last 12 Months | Values 0-7 are monotonically decreasing Max Delinquency Ever | Values 2-8 are monotonically decreasing Number of Total Trades (total number of credit accounts) | No constraint Number of Trades Open in Last12 Months | Monotonically Increasing Percent Installment Trades | No constraint Months Since Most Recent Inquiry excluding last 7 days | Monotonically Decreasing Number of Inquiries Last 6 Months | Monotonically Increasing Number of Inquiries Last 6 Months excluding last 7 days. Excluding the last 7 days removes inquiries that are likely due to price comparison shopping. | Monotonically Increasing Net Fraction Revolving Burden. This is revolving balance divided by credit limit | Monotonically Increasing Net Fraction Installment Burden. This is installment balance divided by original loan amount | Monotonically Increasing Number Revolving Trades with Balance | No constraint Number Installment Trades with Balance | No constraint Number Bank/National Trades with High Utilization Ratio | Monotonically Increasing Percent Trades with Balance | No constraint Risk Performance | Target",

            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

        {
            "abstract": "What is an example of something the training accuracy of? the CEMExplainer algorithm",
            "confidence": 0.37668782472610474,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.37668782472610474,
            "sentence": "To ensure transparency and explainability in our credit approval decisions, we use three different explanatory models: BooleanRuleCG, LogisticRuleRegression, and Generalized Linear Rule Models (GLRM). These models help us understand the reasoning behind the decisions made by our XGBoost model. 1. **BooleanRuleCG (BRCG):** The BooleanRuleCG (BRCG) algorithm generates a set of simple boolean rules using a genetic algorithm. These rules can explain the decisions made by the predictive model, even for complex non-linear relationships. BRCG is designed to produce either a disjunctive normal form (DNF) or a conjunctive normal form (CNF) rule to predict whether an applicant will repay the loan on time. A DNF rule corresponds to an individual rule in the rule set, where the AND clauses in the DNF correspond to individual rules in the rule set. The algorithm uses column generation to search the space of possible clauses, which is exponential in size. The training accuracy of the BRCG model is 0.71, and the test accuracy is 0.69. 2. **LogisticRuleRegression (LRR):** The LogisticRuleRegression (LRR) algorithm fits a logistic regression model using rule-based features and is capable of generating interpretable rules that can explain the decision-making process. It uses column generation to generate promising candidates from the space of all possible rules, including unbinarized ordinal features in addition to rules. The complexity parameters lambda0 and lambda1 penalize the number of rules included in the model and the number of conditions in each rule. The training accuracy of the LRR model is 0.74, and the test accuracy is 0.72. 3. **Generalized Linear Rule Model (GLRM):** The Generalized Linear Rule Model (GLRM) algorithm extends the rule-based explanatory model by allowing for more general linear relationships. It produces models that are weighted combinations of rules, which give insight into loan repayment predictability. The algorithm also has the option of combining rules with linear terms. The model output predicts the probability of repaying on time (Y=1). The training accuracy of the CEMExplainer algorithm is 0.73, and the test accuracy is 0.72.",
            "triple": [
                "my:training_accuracy",
                "my:be_{obj}__{subj}",
                "my:example_of"

            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "abstract": "What is an example of something Our system supports? XAI algorithms",
            "confidence": 0.3776092827320099,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3776092827320099,
            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

            "abstract": "What is an example of something Our system supports? XAI algorithms",
            "confidence": 0.3264877200126648,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3264877200126648,
            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

        },
        {
            "abstract": "What is an example of something the training accuracy of? the CEMExplainer algorithm",
            "confidence": 0.32207873463630676,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.32207873463630676,
            "sentence": "To ensure transparency and explainability in our credit approval decisions, we use three different explanatory models: BooleanRuleCG, LogisticRuleRegression, and Generalized Linear Rule Models (GLRM). These models help us understand the reasoning behind the decisions made by our XGBoost model. 1. **BooleanRuleCG (BRCG):** The BooleanRuleCG (BRCG) algorithm generates a set of simple boolean rules using a genetic algorithm. These rules can explain the decisions made by the predictive model, even for complex non-linear relationships. BRCG is designed to produce either a disjunctive normal form (DNF) or a conjunctive normal form (CNF) rule to predict whether an applicant will repay the loan on time. A DNF rule corresponds to an individual rule in the rule set, where the AND clauses in the DNF correspond to individual rules in the rule set. The algorithm uses column generation to search the space of possible clauses, which is exponential in size. The training accuracy of the BRCG model is 0.71, and the test accuracy is 0.69. 2. **LogisticRuleRegression (LRR):** The LogisticRuleRegression (LRR) algorithm fits a logistic regression model using rule-based features and is capable of generating interpretable rules that can explain the decision-making process. It uses column generation to generate promising candidates from the space of all possible rules, including unbinarized ordinal features in addition to rules. The complexity parameters lambda0 and lambda1 penalize the number of rules included in the model and the number of conditions in each rule. The training accuracy of the LRR model is 0.74, and the test accuracy is 0.72. 3. **Generalized Linear Rule Model (GLRM):** The Generalized Linear Rule Model (GLRM) algorithm extends the rule-based explanatory model by allowing for more general linear relationships. It produces models that are weighted combinations of rules, which give insight into loan repayment predictability. The algorithm also has the option of combining rules with linear terms. The model output predicts the probability of repaying on time (Y=1). The training accuracy of the CEMExplainer algorithm is 0.73, and the test accuracy is 0.72.",
            "triple": [
                "my:training_accuracy",
                "my:be_{obj}__{subj}",
                "my:example_of"
            ],
            "source_id": "_:cas_v1.md_s30",
            "source_sentence_uri": null

            "abstract": "What is an example of algorithms we use? The algorithms we use are: *",

            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3885168433189392,
            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

            "abstract": "While what do we use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics? During the development of the machine learning model",
            "confidence": 0.3773675858974457,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.3773675858974457,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

        {
            "abstract": "the features that contribute to a customer 's creditworthiness",
            "confidence": 0.4803112745285034,
            "syntactic_similarity": 0,
            "semantic_similarity": 0.4803112745285034,
            "sentence": "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",

            "sentence": "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",

<Question> Does the documentation include a general description stating the intended purpose of the AI system?
<Answers> [
    "Our objective is to ensure that our AI system is transparent, fair, and robust, while providing a high degree of explainability to both our internal teams and external stakeholders.",
    "A key feature of our AI system is its explainability. We believe it's essential for data scientists, loan officers, and bank customers to understand the reasoning behind the credit approval decisions made by the system. The system incorporates built-in human oversight to ensure that the outputs are correct. The models are designed to be transparent, so their workings can be easily understood. They are also monitored during deployment, and adjustments can be made as necessary.",
    "This technical documentation provides a comprehensive overview of the AI-based Credit Approval System designed by our company in adherence to the strict requirements of the EU AI Act. The system assesses the creditworthiness of loan applicants, falling under the high-risk category of AI-based systems. Our objective is to ensure that our AI system is transparent, fair, and robust, while providing a high degree of explainability to both our internal teams and external stakeholders.",
    "A key feature of our AI system is its explainability.",
    "This monitoring process also enables the system to adapt to changing trends and operate in compliance with the EU AI Act.",
    "Based on the findings from data analysis and regular testing, the AI system will be periodically updated and maintained.",
    "The lifecycle comprises three stages: monitoring, testing, and reporting. **Monitoring.** During the monitoring phase, we gather data on the system's real-world performance. This includes system inputs and outputs, user feedback, and any errors or anomalies that might occur. **Testing.** In the testing phase, the AI system is subjected to various scenarios to assess its robustness, accuracy, and performance. This includes testing the system with new, unseen data to ensure it can generalize well beyond the initial training set. **Reporting.** The reporting phase involves generating comprehensive reports on the system's performance, including any issues identified during monitoring and testing, as well as any corrective actions taken. These reports are then submitted to the relevant regulatory authorities, ensuring we maintain full transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements.",
    "The AI-based credit approval system is designed to continually learn and improve from the new data it encounters post-deployment.",
    "By following these steps and utilizing the aif360 toolkit, we can ensure that our credit approval system is fair and unbiased, reducing the risk of discrimination and promoting ethical and responsible use of AI-based systems.",
    "In the testing phase, the AI system is subjected to various scenarios to assess its robustness, accuracy, and performance.",
    "The model's performance is evaluated using the testing set, which gives us a realistic measure of how the model will perform in real-world scenarios. The model is regularly monitored and updated to detect and address emerging biases promptly. This monitoring process also enables the system to adapt to changing trends and operate in compliance with the EU AI Act. ### Dataset Variables",
    "To ensure that the system maintains its performance and complies with the EU AI Act requirements, a lifecycle has been established to evaluate its performance in the post-market phase.",
    "Let's dive into the specifics of our AI system, beginning with our data source and how we preprocess and train our models. ## Data Source, Pre-processing, and Training",
    "Based on the findings from data analysis and regular testing, the AI system will be periodically updated and maintained. These updates might include changes to the machine learning model, the data processing methods, or the user interface. ### Stakeholder Feedback",
    "Each section includes a detailed account of our procedures, methodologies, and commitments, providing clear insights into our AI system's operations. By the end of this document, readers should have a thorough understanding of how our Credit Approval AI System functions, how it meets the EU AI Act's requirements, and how we plan to maintain and improve its performance post-deployment.",
    "The AI-based credit approval system is designed to continually learn and improve from the new data it encounters post-deployment. To ensure that the system maintains its performance and complies with the EU AI Act requirements, a lifecycle has been established to evaluate its performance in the post-market phase.",
    "Each user group has unique needs and the system accordingly provides tailored explanation methods for machine learning predictions.",
    "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",
    "In addition to these XAI tools, we use GitHub to track and audit the development of our AI system. Every change is logged and timestamped to ensure transparency and accountability. We also keep third-party tools up to date and ensure their security to maintain the system's high standards and comply with all relevant regulations. ## Lifecycle for Evaluating AI System Performance in the Post-Market Phase",
    "The following are the system requirements for the AI-based Credit Approval System: - Operating System: Compatibility with Windows, Linux, and macOS. - Processor: A minimum requirement of an Intel Core i5 processor."
]
<Final Answer> Yes, the documentation includes a general description stating the intended purpose of the AI system. The AI-based Credit Approval System is designed to assess the creditworthiness of loan applicants, falling under the high-risk category of AI-based systems. The system is designed to be transparent, fair, and robust, with a high degree of explainability for both internal teams and external stakeholders. It also incorporates built-in human oversight to ensure the outputs are correct and is designed to continually learn and improve from new data it encounters post-deployment (Paragraph 2, 1, 7).

    "These requirements may be subject to changes depending on the system configuration and the volume of data involved.",
    "They are also monitored during deployment, and adjustments can be made as necessary.",
    "The following are the system requirements for the AI-based Credit Approval System: - Operating System: Compatibility with Windows, Linux, and macOS. - Processor: A minimum requirement of an Intel Core i5 processor. - RAM: At least 8 GB for optimal performance. - Storage: A minimum of 100 GB of free disk space. - Graphics Card: A dedicated Nvidia graphics card, such as Nvidia A100. - Internet Connection: A stable connection for seamless API access. - Additional Software: Python 3.6 or later, CUDA 10.0, and cuDNN 7.6.5 or later."
]
<Final Answer> Yes, there are requirements related to version updates. The AI system will be periodically updated and maintained, which might include changes to the machine learning model, the data processing methods, or the user interface (paragraph 1). Third-party tools are also kept up to date and their security is ensured to maintain the system's high standards and comply with all relevant regulations (paragraph 2). Every change is logged and timestamped to ensure transparency and accountability (paragraph 3). These requirements may be subject to changes depending on the system configuration and the volume of data involved (paragraph 4).

<Final Answer> Yes, the hardware on which the AI system is intended to run is described. The system requirements for the AI-based Credit Approval System include compatibility with Windows, Linux, and macOS operating systems, a minimum requirement of an Intel Core i5 processor, at least 8 GB of RAM, a minimum of 100 GB of free disk space, a dedicated Nvidia graphics card such as Nvidia A100, and a stable internet connection. Additional software requirements include Python 3.6 or later, CUDA 10.0, and cuDNN 7.6.5 or later (paragraph 0). The system also underwent an intensive training period of approximately 8 hours on 8x NVIDIA A100 to ensure optimal performance (paragraph 1).

The system incorporates built-in human oversight to ensure that the outputs are correct. The models are designed to be transparent, so their workings can be easily understood. This includes system inputs and outputs, user feedback, and any errors or anomalies that might occur. **Testing.** In the testing phase, the AI system is subjected to various scenarios to assess its robustness, accuracy, and performance. This includes testing the system with new, unseen data to ensure it can generalize well beyond the initial training set. **Reporting.** The reporting phase involves generating comprehensive reports on the system's performance, including any issues identified during monitoring and testing, as well as any corrective actions taken. Our objective is to ensure that our AI system is transparent, fair, and robust, while providing a high degree of explainability to both our internal teams and external stakeholders.",
    "This technical documentation provides a comprehensive overview of the AI-based Credit Approval System designed by our company in adherence to the strict requirements of the EU AI Act.",
    "Let's dive into the specifics of our AI system, beginning with our data source and how we preprocess and train our models.",
    "In addition to these XAI tools, we use GitHub to track and audit the development of our AI system.",
    "Our system also supports XAI algorithms for explaining credit approval decisions to loan officers and bank customers. The algorithms we use are: * **ProtodashExplainer:** This XAI tool is for producing explanations for Loan Officers/employees. The ProtodashExplainer algorithm works with an existing predictive model to show how the customer compares to others who have similar profiles and had similar repayment records to the model's prediction for the current customer. It helps to evaluate and predict the applicant's risk. The method takes as input a datapoint (or group of datapoints) that we want to explain with respect to instances in a training set belonging to the same feature space. The method then tries to minimize the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD metric) between the datapoints we want to explain and a prespecified number of instances from the training set that it will select. * **CEMExplainer:** This XAI tool is for Applicants/bank customers. The CEMExplainer algorithm sits on top of an existing predictive model and helps detect both the features that a bank customer could improve and also further detects the features that will increase the likelihood of approval and those that are within reach for the customer. It provides insight into what - if their application was rejected - they can improve in order to increase the likelihood it will be accepted in the future.",
    "We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset.",

    "The lifecycle comprises three stages: monitoring, testing, and reporting. **Monitoring.** During the monitoring phase, we gather data on the system's real-world performance. This includes system inputs and outputs, user feedback, and any errors or anomalies that might occur. **Testing.** In the testing phase, the AI system is subjected to various scenarios to assess its robustness, accuracy, and performance. This includes testing the system with new, unseen data to ensure it can generalize well beyond the initial training set. **Reporting.** The reporting phase involves generating comprehensive reports on the system's performance, including any issues identified during monitoring and testing, as well as any corrective actions taken. These reports are then submitted to the relevant regulatory authorities, ensuring we maintain full transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements.",
    "A key feature of our AI system is its explainability. We believe it's essential for data scientists, loan officers, and bank customers to understand the reasoning behind the credit approval decisions made by the system. The system incorporates built-in human oversight to ensure that the outputs are correct. The models are designed to be transparent, so their workings can be easily understood. They are also monitored during deployment, and adjustments can be made as necessary.",
    "In addition to these XAI tools, we use GitHub to track and audit the development of our AI system. Every change is logged and timestamped to ensure transparency and accountability. We also keep third-party tools up to date and ensure their security to maintain the system's high standards and comply with all relevant regulations. ## Lifecycle for Evaluating AI System Performance in the Post-Market Phase",
    "Before the data is used to train the credit approval AI model, we follow a pre-processing phase that involves several steps to ensure data quality, integrity, fairness, and non-discrimination. We describe these steps below: **Data Cleaning.** We begin by meticulously removing any inconsistencies, errors, or duplicates in the credit approval dataset to ensure data quality and integrity. **Feature Selection.** We identify and select the most relevant features that contribute to a customer's creditworthiness using both domain knowledge and feature importance techniques. This process helps to ensure that only the most relevant features are used to train our model. **Data Normalization.** We normalize the data to ensure that all features have a similar scale. Normalizing the data helps our model to train more effectively and avoid bias towards any specific feature. This step is crucial in preventing bias towards specific features that may have a larger scale than others. **Data Bias Reduction.** To ensure fairness and non-discrimination in our credit approval system, we use the Reweighing algorithm to reduce bias in the training data. Specifically, we follow the steps below: 1. **Loading and Preparing Data:** We load the initial credit approval dataset and split it into training and testing datasets. We use the testing dataset to assess the accuracy, fairness, and other metrics during the development of the machine learning model. 2. **Computing Fairness Metric on Original Training Dataset:** We use the AI Fairness 360 (aif360) toolkit to compute the fairness metric on the original training dataset. We identify the protected attribute 'age' and define privileged and unprivileged values for that attribute. We then use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class to compare the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group. A negative value indicates less favorable outcomes for the unprivileged group. 3. **Mitigating Bias by Transforming the Original Dataset:** To mitigate bias in the training dataset, we use the Reweighing algorithm implemented in the Reweighing class in the aif360.algorithms.preprocessing package. This algorithm transforms the dataset to have more equity in positive outcomes on the protected attribute for the privileged and unprivileged groups. We use the fit and transform methods to perform the transformation, producing a newly transformed training dataset. 4. **Computing Fairness Metric on Transformed Dataset:** We use the mean_difference method on the BinaryLabelDatasetMetric class again to compute the fairness metric on the transformed training dataset. This metric indicates the percentage of favorable outcomes for each group after the dataset has been transformed. We see that the Reweighing algorithm was highly effective in removing bias, as the difference in mean outcomes is now 0.0. Therefore, there is no advantage for the privileged group.",
    "This technical documentation provides a comprehensive overview of the AI-based Credit Approval System designed by our company in adherence to the strict requirements of the EU AI Act.",

    "The model's performance is evaluated using the testing set, which gives us a realistic measure of how the model will perform in real-world scenarios.
